title: How Recruiters Actually Read Resumes
subtitle: Eye-tracking research shows recruiters spend an average of 7.4 seconds on initial resume screening in the 2018 update, up from about 6 seconds in 2012. Here is what they look at, and what your resume needs to survive the skim.

studySnapshot.whatItStudied: How professional recruiters visually scan resumes during initial screening
studySnapshot.keyFinding: 2018 update reported ~7.4 seconds for the initial fit/no-fit decision, up from ~6 seconds in 2012
studySnapshot.soWhatForResumes: The top of your resume carries more weight than the rest of the page combined

figures.title: Resume scanning zones based on eye-tracking data
figures.caption: Eye-tracking shows recruiters spend the majority of their initial scan on the top third of the page. The 'golden triangle' receives the most attention.

keyInsights.title: Name and title get the most attention
keyInsights.explanation: Eye tracking heatmaps show the name/title area receives the longest fixation time during initial scan.
keyInsights.riypImplication: Recruiter First Impression highlights how clearly your title and current role come across.

keyInsights.title: Current role is scanned second
keyInsights.explanation: After the header, eyes move to the most recent jobâ€”title, company, and dates.
keyInsights.riypImplication: Our main score weights your current role description heavily.

keyInsights.title: Numbers catch the eye
keyInsights.explanation: The 'spotted pattern' shows eyes jump to metrics, dollar amounts, and percentages.
keyInsights.riypImplication: Bullet Upgrades push numbers toward the front of each bullet.

keyInsights.title: Dense text gets skimmed over
keyInsights.explanation: Resumes with clear headings and consistent formatting got more focused attention.
keyInsights.riypImplication: We flag overly long bullets and suggest breaking them up.

riypChanges.why: we simulate what a recruiter notices in their first scan, based on eye-tracking data.
we push numbers toward the front of bullets, where eyes land during the spotted pattern.
we flag dense walls of text that get skimmed over during fast scans.
